moves.1. e4: Nick (moistcomrade) had previously played two games against sabyyavin, for which he lost both because he cracked under the pressure of being behind in material. Nick already drops a rook early, and whilst most players would have given up, Nick gallantly fought on and against the material deficit, generated a strong attack. Black still maintains a material advantage after the exchange of queens, but makes a costly blunder and White queens his pawn. Even with accurate defence, Black could have drawn the game, but he ends up dropping a rook at the end, and concedes.
moves.1... d5 2. exd5 Nf6 3. Nc3 Nxd5 4. Nxd5: Probably a weakening move; 9. d3 is stronger.
moves.9... Qc5 10. d3 Qb6 11. Be3 Qxb2 12. Bc1: It unfortunately took Nick about a second to realise his mistake. 12. Ng5 keeps Black's advantage to a minimum.
15....Qb6 would be a better dark square, and would eventually force the exchange of queens, Black would push home his advantage.
moves.16. Bf3 e4 17. Bxe4 Bxe4 18. Rxe4 Qd2 19: White is trying to free the back rank for his king, but Black has no immediate mate threats. 19. Re3 is better, guarding the d3 pawn.
moves.19... Bc5: Even so, taking immediately would have been better.
moves.20. Rf4 Rxd3 21. Qb5 Qd1+ 22. Kg2 Bb6 23: White has two pins against Black's king, and looks dangerous.
moves.27... Kb8 28. Qe5+ Ka8 29. Qf5 Qb1: Black is threatening Rxg3+, because of the pin, but he failed to realise 30. Bxd8! Rxg3+ 31. Kxg3 Qxf5?? 32. Bc7+ mates.
moves.30... Qxa2 31. Be7: White should have captured. He is hoping for 31...Rxe7?? 32. Qc8# but Black sees through right his trap.
moves.31... Qxc4: 31...Qe2 is better. Black would have maintained his rook advantage. Still, Black remains material up.
moves.32. Bxd8 b5 33. Bf6+ Kb7 34. f3 Rd3d2+ 3: Nick is down the exchange and a few pawns, but puts his faith in the passed pawns.
moves.37. Rh8 b4 38. Rxh7 b3 39. h4 Rd5d2: a slight error; maybe 39...a5, pushing the pawns, was better.
moves.40. g5 Kc7: again, 40...a5 was better. White's passed pawn on the h-file is very difficult to stop.
Black's advantage is now minimal, and White will queen his pawn. Significantly better was 45...Rb1! where Black will be able to get behind the pawn. After a long variation, Black will take the passed pawn and push home his material advantage.
moves.46. h7 f6: Again, 46...Rd1 would have been better. For the first time in the game, White has the advantage, courtesy of Computer Analysis @ Gameknot.
moves.47. Rb8+: Maybe 47. g6 first, creating another passed pawn? Then 47...R2d5 48. Rb8+ Kxb8 49. h8=Q+ Kb7 50. Kh3 Ka6 51. Qxf6 keeps material close to level, with good drawing chances for Black.
moves.50. Qe5 Kb7 51. Qb2+ Ka8 52. Kg4 Rd7d8 5: 55...R8d2 would have been better, maintaining the pressure on the queen.
moves.56. Qc2: White's idea is 57. g7 Rxg7?? 58. Qb2+.
moves.56... Rg8: And Black falls for the trap on a similar variation; 56...Rd2 gives White a small advantage, but nothing immediate.
moves.57. Qb3+: And so Black gave up. Incredible that White fought on after dropping a rook, and worked his way back into the match, and when Black drops a rook, he resigns. Incredible game!
